code: @Manual{,   title = {gtseq: Visualizing biological sequences with gt},   author = {Victor Yuan},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9002},   url = {http://victoryuan.com/gtseq/}, }

title: Visualizing biological sequences with gt
text: goal gtseq provide smalle modular functions help visualize biological sequences gt. R package developed part 2025 posit table contest. See submission details. Traditionally, analysis related biological sequences multiple sequence alignment (MSA) done standalone software programs like Jalview, Rasmol, many others, online web apps like NCBI’s msa viewer. Recent additions like ggmsa, Bioconductor’s msa, among others, brought visualization analysis R ecosystem. sequences often visualized table packages like gt. package facilitates bringing traditional bioinformatic activities R gt.

title: Visualizing biological sequences with gt
text: can install development version gtseq GitHub :

title: Visualizing biological sequences with gt
text: gtseq provides several functions help create gt tables biological sequences. Although philosophy provide small modular functions allow high customizability, gtseq::gtseq wrapper function provided quickly efficiently explore sequences. Use gtseq data.frame column containing amino acid sequences: customization use lower-level functions:

title: Visualizing biological sequences with gt
text: split_sequences structuring data gt, output function retains 1 sequence per row structure, splits element sequence data, maximum flexibility customization gt
code: library(gt) msa |> split_sequences(seq_column = seq) #> # A tibble: 8 × 98 #>   group name  start pos_1 pos_2 pos_3 pos_4 pos_5 pos_6 pos_7 pos_8 pos_9 pos_10 #>   <chr> <chr> <dbl> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr>  #> 1 beta  OC43   1225 T     S     I     P     N     L     P     D     F     K      #> 2 beta  MHV    1191 T     S     I     P     N     P     P     D     F     K      #> 3 beta  HKU1   1226 H     S     V     P     K     L     S     D     F     E      #> 4 beta  SARS   1122 P     L     Q     P     E     L     D     S     F     K      #> 5 beta  SARS2  1140 P     L     Q     P     E     L     D     S     F     K      #> 6 beta  MERS   1223 L     G     N     S     T     G     I     D     F     Q      #> 7 alpha 229E   1025 T     I     V     P     E     Y     I     D     V     N      #> 8 alpha NL63   1208 T     V     I     P     D     Y     V     D     V     N      #> # ℹ 85 more variables: pos_11 <chr>, pos_12 <chr>, pos_13 <chr>, pos_14 <chr>, #> #   pos_15 <chr>, pos_16 <chr>, pos_17 <chr>, pos_18 <chr>, pos_19 <chr>, #> #   pos_20 <chr>, pos_21 <chr>, pos_22 <chr>, pos_23 <chr>, pos_24 <chr>, #> #   pos_25 <chr>, pos_26 <chr>, pos_27 <chr>, pos_28 <chr>, pos_29 <chr>, #> #   pos_30 <chr>, pos_31 <chr>, pos_32 <chr>, pos_33 <chr>, pos_34 <chr>, #> #   pos_35 <chr>, pos_36 <chr>, pos_37 <chr>, pos_38 <chr>, pos_39 <chr>, #> #   pos_40 <chr>, pos_41 <chr>, pos_42 <chr>, pos_43 <chr>, pos_44 <chr>, …

title: Visualizing biological sequences with gt
text: apply_color_to_aa coloring amino acids one included palettes function returned, takes input colors according given palette function can directly passed gt::data_color
code: apply_color_to_aa("Chemistry")(c("A", "K", "L", "-")) #>         A         K         L         -  #> "#f2be3c" "#769dcc" "#f2be3c" "#ffffff" msa |>   split_sequences(seq_column = seq) |>   gt() |>   data_color(columns = contains('pos_'), fn = apply_color_to_aa('Chemistry'))

title: Visualizing biological sequences with gt
text: get_consensus adding consensus sequence frequency data. Pass either gt::grand_summary_rows gt::summary_rows.
code: msa |>   split_sequences(seq_column = seq) |>   gt() |>   data_color(columns = contains('pos_'), fn = apply_color_to_aa('Chemistry')) |>   grand_summary_rows(     columns = contains('pos_'),     fns = list(       consensus = ~ get_consensus(.)     )   )

title: Visualizing biological sequences with gt
text: Takes vector returns every nth element, based scales::breaks_width allows applying label every nth position sequences gt::cols_label_with
code: library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union cnames <- msa |>   split_sequences(seq_column = seq) |>   select(contains('pos_')) |>   colnames() breaks <- generate_breaks(cnames) breaks #>  [1] "pos_5"  "pos_10" "pos_15" "pos_20" "pos_25" "pos_30" "pos_35" "pos_40" #>  [9] "pos_45" "pos_50" "pos_55" "pos_60" "pos_65" "pos_70" "pos_75" "pos_80" #> [17] "pos_85" "pos_90" "pos_95" msa |>   split_sequences(seq_column = seq) |>   gt() |>   data_color(columns = contains('pos_'), fn = apply_color_to_aa('Chemistry')) |>   cols_label_with(     columns = contains('pos_'),     fn = ~ ifelse(. %in% breaks, gsub('pos_', '', .), '')   )

title: function that takes a dataframe, with sequences in one column, and creates a gt table — gtseq
code: gtseq(   df,   seq_column,   names_prefix = "pos_",   rowname_col = NULL,   groupname_col = dplyr::group_vars(df),   process_md = FALSE,   caption = NULL,   rownames_to_stub = FALSE,   row_group_as_column = FALSE,   auto_align = TRUE,   id = NULL,   locale = getOption("gt.locale"),   row_group.sep = getOption("gt.row_group.sep", " - ") )
